Posted By: Doom_Lich (5/21/2010 8:59:14 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: This card is going to be a very common card in any monogreen beatdown deck for a long time. It's a super efficient token maker, and is a decently sized body by itself. Best part is it's pretty effective vs. removal heavy decks. Unless your opponent is running [Day of Judgment](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Day of Judgment) they're going to have to spend at least 2 cards on removing all your wolves and the baseline elemental. ([Volcanic Fallout](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Volcanic Fallout)+[Lighting bolt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lighting bolt), which really means you've won out in the overall exchange.)
posts.html:

Best part is it's pretty effective vs. removal heavy decks. Unless your opponent is running Day of Judgment they're going to have to spend at least 2 cards on removing all your wolves and the baseline elemental. (Volcanic Fallout+Lighting bolt, which really means you've won out in the overall exchange.)

posts.post_content:
I love this card. I have it in a stereotypical mono-green deck and will never replace it. It also unexpectidly combos very well with [Mossbridge Troll](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mossbridge Troll). Play the wolf and kick for 5, an easy number to reach with green ramp or [Omnath, Locus of Mana](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Omnath, Locus of Mana), then play the Troll next turn and get a 25/25 creature after that.   
  
I won with that combo after playing a [Bellowing Tanglewurm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bellowing Tanglewurm) and killed my opponent after not attacking a single time before that. :)  
  
5/5
posts.html:

Posted By: Voriki (10/8/2011 3:40:10 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Run this with [Erratic Portal](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Erratic Portal) (or [Crystal Shard](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Crystal Shard) in a {U}/{G} deck) to increase your pack every turn! This tactic is especially powerful in EDH games that tend to go long... nothing like having a regrowing pack of 9+ wolves every turn if you don't have anything better to put out, or are waiting for the opportune moment to cast a something.  
  
This tactic is even better with [Master of the Wild Hunt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Master of the Wild Hunt) or [Wren's Run Packmaster](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wren's Run Packmaster) to back it up. Wolves of instant death? yes plz.
posts.html:

Posted By: SirShadow (9/5/2012 12:41:31 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
This card cannot be compared to continuous token generators like [Bitterblossom](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bitterblossom) or [Master of the Wild Hunt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Master of the Wild Hunt) or repeatable activated token generation like [Wren's Run Packmaster](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wren's Run Packmaster): it's a different strategy. Continuous token generators require time, while activated requires a lot of mana (![2](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=2&type=symbol)![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol) for each token); this one instead gives 2/2 wolves for ![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol) each, but you can only "buy" them when casting it. This card requires a strong mana investment when cast, while Wren's Run Packmaster is always at your disposal but require THREE TIMES more mana to give a wolf...  
  
It's not bad, but I personally think [Khalni Hydra](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Khalni Hydra) is better.
posts.html:
This card cannot be compared to continuous token generators like Bitterblossom or Master of the Wild Hunt or repeatable activated token generation like Wren's Run Packmaster: it's a different strategy. Continuous token generators require time, while activated requires a lot of mana ( for each token); this one instead gives 2/2 wolves for each, but you can only "buy" them when casting it. This card requires a strong mana investment when cast, while Wren's Run Packmaster is always at your disposal but require THREE TIMES more mana to give a wolf...

It's not bad, but I personally think Khalni Hydra is better.

posts.post_content:
You've ramped to 10 mana in the late game of a game and play this guy, kicking him 6 times. How is 15 points of power for 10 mana a bad deal at all?  
  
Basically, he's 'ok' in the mid game, but if you draw him late game he can be a very potent win con.

posts.post_content: No matter what mana cost you play him at there's a better option for that cost but he's pretty reasonable. Good anywhere along your curve which makes him good for unpredictable singleton formats or in aggro decks that wouldn't mind a big cost finisher for when their turn three and four plays have fallen short. When I first the multikicker that gave 2/2s for just G I freaked out but I see now that this is a powerful but superbly balanced card.
posts.html:
